abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey satisfactory project
            outcomes, a highly likely sustainability, with high
            institutional development impacts, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Several lessons
            drawn from the project suggest: a) continuity, and top
            quality of key personnel from both the Bank, and Borrower
            are important factors, that ensured a successful project; b)
            appropriate monitoring indicators are important to assess
            project achievements: while these were provided in the staff
            appraisal report, it is important that all base line data be
            determined at appraisal, and agreed early on, otherwise the
            project agencies may experience difficulty in properly
            applying the indicators to monitor project outcome and
            outputs; c) the high operational costs associated with
            secondary wastewater treatment (as at Songjiang), and sludge
            disposal, compared with preliminary or primary treatment,
            are not always appreciated by government, and implementing
            agencies; rather, for long-term sustainability of secondary
            wastewater facilities, it is important that wastewater
            tariffs adequately provide sufficient revenue to meet these
            operational costs, and ensure sustainable operations. Costs
            may also be reduced with further technical refinements, in
            particular regarding energy efficiency; d) for political and
            social reasons, governments are often reluctant to sanction
            large increases in water and wastewater user charges,
            preferring to raise charges by small increments. Executing
            agencies remained in substantial non-compliance with
            financial targets throughout the project, which highlights
            the need for a different approach, such as the establishment
            of a more independent regulatory authority with power to
            review and approve tariffs. Further lessons recommend strong
            institutional strengthening through technical assistance;
            building arrangements for public-private partnerships;
            identification, and monitoring of appropriate procurement
            procedures; and, adequate project coordination, and skills
            training provision.
